cab.content: maximum DQCUMEHT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'8 GOVERNMENT-Printed for the War Cabinet. May1943.SECRET.W.M. (43)75th Conclusions.Copy No. 50TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND key it is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document war CABINET 75 (43).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street,S.W. 1, on Sunday, May 23, 1943, at 9 p m.Present:The Right Hon. C. R. Attlee, M.P., Deputy Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon.; Ernest Bevin, M.P.,Minister of Labour and NationalService.The Right Hon. Herbert Morrison,M.P., Secretary of State for theHome Department and Minister ofHome Security.The Right Hon. Oliver Lyttelton.M.P., Minister of Production.The following were also presentThe Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood, I The Right Hon. Viscount Cranborne,M P Chancellor of the Exchequer, j Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon. A. V. Alexander,M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.The Right Hon. Brendan Bracken,M.P., Minister of InformationrThe Right Hon. Sir James Grigg,M.P., Secretary of State for War.The Right Hon. Sir Stafford Crd?ps,K.C., M.P.", Minister of aircraft production.The Hon. Sir Alexander Cadogan,Permanent Under-Secretary of. Statefor Foreign Affairs.Sir Edward Brddges, Secretary.Contents.minute no.1 France ... ........General de Gaulle and General GiraudSubject. pa9e......... li .... 562 Russia .... ..........Abolition of the Comintern.3 France ................The French Fleet at Alexandria.[25486]5656 France.General . 'de Gaulle andGeneral Giraud., (previous reference:W.M. (43) 48thConclusions,Minute 4.)1. The War Cabinet had before them three telegrams frOm thePrime Minister (Pencil Nos. 166, 167 and 181) reporting the viewsheld in America about relations between General die Gaulle andGeneral Giraud, and making certain proposals.The War Cabinet, after discussion, settled the terms of threetelegrams to be sent to the Prime Minister.setting out their views on the matter (see Alcove Nos. 370, 371 and 372).A full record of the discussion and of the Conclusions reached is contained in the SecretaryY Standard File of War cabinet conclusions.Russia. 2. The War Cabinet had under consideration the publicAbolition of announcement by the Soviet Government of. the abolition of thethe Comintern. Comintern. '- The War Cabinet decided that it would be undesirable that His. Majesty's Government should make known their views on this development at this stage.France.The french fleet at alexandria.(previous reference:W.M. (43) 74thConclusions,Minute 3.)3. The War Cabinet were informed that it was now clear that admiral Godfroy had sent a signal to the Vichy Governmentannouncing his decision to transfer his allegiance, and that of hissquadron, to General Giraud. It was not thought, however, thatthe fact that this action had been taken would lead to the Admiralnot carrying out his decision to transfer his allegiance.Offices of the War Cabinet, S. W. 1,May 24, 1943.
